titleInfo.title: Louisiana Cooperative Extension Oral History Project
titleInfo.subTitle: Kenneth Roberts oral history interview, 2014

name.description: Kenneth Roberts was born on September 19, 1944, in New Orleans, Louisiana. He is the son of well-known meteorologist Nash C. Roberts and Lydia Leblanc. He grew up in Metairie, Louisiana. He attended public schools and participated in the 4-H club in high school. He started his academic career at the University of New Orleans before transferring to Louisiana State University where he earned his bachelor's and master's degrees in agricultural economics. After receiving his master's degree, Roberts moved to Oregon where he attended Oregon State University. His Ph.D. is in natural resource economics. Upon graduation from OSU, Roberts worked as a natural resource economist and program director for the Clemson University Sea Grant program. He then spent a year working for the National Sea Grant office as a program monitor before returning to South Carolina. In 1978, Roberts returned to Louisiana as a Marine Extension resource economist for Louisiana Sea Grant. In 2001, he became the associate vice chancellor and associate director of Extension for the Louisiana State University Ag Center. He retired from the LSU Ag Center in the fall of 2006.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Roberts discusses his father's career as a meteorologist for the major television networks. He also provides insight into his 4-H club member days and his schooling, particularly his time at the University of New Orleans and his doctoral work at Oregon State University. He primarily focuses on his career with Sea Grant, documenting his time with Clemson University, the National Sea Grant program, and then as a marine economist for Louisiana Sea Grant. Roberts gives insight into the revolutionary nature of his split research and extension appointment, how technology and personal computers impacted extension work, racial tensions with Vietnamese and Cambodian fishermen, and the relationship between the oil industry and Louisiana fisheries. He also describes how the fishing industry is traditionally a male-dominated industry; the prevailing theme of wages among fishermen; and the political impact of federal, state, and local money in extension. Roberts then discusses the need for the quality control of information within the extension model.
